questions.text:
Match the following conditions with their most commonly involved sites.
Condition Site
1. True diverticulum A. Terminal ileum
2. Acquired diverticulum     B. Ileum
3. Crohn's disease C. Colorectum
4. Polyps D. Sigmoid colon
questions.solution:
The most common sites of the following conditions are: 

Condition Site
1. True diverticulum B. Ileum
2. Acquired diverticulum D. Sigmoid colon
3. Crohn's disease A. Terminal ileum
4. Polyps C. Colorectum

A true diverticulum is a blind outpouching of the alimentary tract that communicates with the lumen and includes all three layers of the bowel wall. The most common true diverticulum is Meckel's diverticulum. It most commonly occurs in the ileum. It occurs as a result of the failed involution of the vitelline duct, which connects the lumen of the developing gut to the yolk sac.

The following image shows a Meckel's diverticulum.

On the other hand, false or acquired diverticula either lack the muscularis entirely or have an attenuated muscularis propria.

Though Crohn's disease most commonly occurs in the terminal ileum, it may occur in any area of the GI tract.

Polyps are most common in the colorectal region. They can be sessile (without stalk) or pedunculated (with stalk). Intestinal polyps can be classified as non-neoplastic or neoplastic in nature. The nonneoplastic polyps can be further classified as inflammatory, hamartomatous, or hyperplastic. The most common neoplastic polyp is an adenoma.

Related Pearl: Rule of two’s in Meckel's diverticulum

  • 2% prevalence
  • 2:1 male predominance
  • Located approx 2 feet (60 cm) proximal to the ileocecal valve in adults
  • Approx 2 inches in length
  • Half of those who are symptomatic are under 2 years of age.
  • 2 types of heterotopic mucosa (gastric & pancreatic)

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the pathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease?

choices.text: Failure of migration of neural crest cells

questions.solution:
Hirschsprung disease occurs due to the failure of migration of the neural crest cells to the bowel wall.

During normal embryogenesis, the neural crest cells migrate from the caecum to the rectum. The enteric neuronal plexuses develop from these migrated neural crest cells.

In Hirschsprung disease, there is an arrest in the migration of these cells, which leads to the development of a distal intestinal segment that is devoid of Meissner (submucosal) and the Auerbach (myenteric) plexus. Hence this segment is referred to as the aganglionic segment.

As a result, there is a lack of coordination in the peristaltic contractions and functional obstruction, which further leads to the dilation of the intestine proximal to the affected segment, leading to congenital megacolon. Diagnosis is confirmed by demonstrating the absence of ganglion cells in biopsy sections.

Some conditions may cause acquired megacolon. These include:

  • Chagas disease, due to the loss of ganglion cells
  • Visceral myopathy
  • Obstruction by neoplasm or inflammatory stricture
  • Toxic megacolon complicating ulcerative colitis
  • Functional psychosomatic disorders

questions.text: A male infant, with a history of not passing meconium, presented with abdominal distension 2 days after birth. Barium enema showed marked colonic dilation above a narrow segment in the sigmoid region. A biopsy specimen from the narrowed region demonstrated absence of ganglion cells. This disease may be associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Hirschsprung disease. It is associated with Down's syndrome.

Hirschsprung disease is also known as congenital aganglionic megacolon. 10% of all cases occur in children with Down's syndrome.

The premature arrest of normal migration of neural crest cells from the cecum to the rectum produces aganglionosis of the distal intestinal segment. This causes functional obstruction of the affected bowel and proximal dilation. The absence of ganglion cells in the affected segment in biopsy confirms the diagnosis.

Gastrointestinal abnormalities associated with Down's syndrome include:

  • Duodenal atresia
  • Annular pancreas
  • Hirschsprung disease

Gastrointestinal abnormalities associated with Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18) include:

  • Meckel's diverticulum
  • Malrotation

Gastrointestinal abnormalities associated with Patau syndrome (trisomy 13) include:

  • Omphalocele
  • Incomplete rotation of the colon
  • Meckel's diverticulum

questions.text: What is the most common site of volvulus?
questions.solution:
The most common site of volvulus is the sigmoid colon.

The twisting of a loop of the bowel about its mesenteric point of attachment is termed volvulus. Segments involved in volvulus in the decreasing order of frequency are:

  • Sigmoid colon
  • Cecum
  • Small bowel
  • Stomach
  • Transverse colon

questions.text: What is the most common site of gastrointestinal ischemia?
questions.solution:
The most common site of gastrointestinal ischemia is the colon.

Intestinal segments at the end of their respective arterial supplies are particularly susceptible to ischemia. These are termed watershed zones. These include:

  • Splenic flexure - where the superior and inferior mesenteric arterial circulations terminate
  • Junction of sigmoid colon and rectum - where the inferior mesenteric, pudendal, and iliac arterial circulations end

questions.text: Campylobacter infection can result in all of the following complications except:
questions.solution:
Aplastic crisis is associated with parvovirus infection, not Campylobacter infection.

Campylobacter infection can cause:

  • Reactive arthritis, primarily in patients with HLA-B27
  • Erythema nodosum
  • Guillain–Barré syndrome (GBS)

Molecular mimicry has been implicated in the pathogenesis of GBS because serum antibodies to Campylobacter jejuni lipopolysaccharide crossreact with peripheral and central nervous system gangliosides.

questions.text: A pathologist is examining the following histopathological specimen from a patient with watery diarrhea and abdominal pain. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows superficially damaged crypts with a typical pattern of mucopurulent exudates (neutrophils) emanating from a crypt that resembles a volcanic eruption. This is pathognomonic of Clostridium difficile colitis.

In this condition, disruption of the normal colonic microbiota by antibiotics allows C. difficile overgrowth. 

Risk factors for Clostridium difficile colitis are:

  • Antibiotic use
  • Advanced age
  • Gastric suppression- PPIs, H2 receptor blockers
  • Immunosuppression

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with loose stools and right lower abdominal pain for the past 6 months. Endoscopy was done which showed skip lesions with a cobblestone appearance. Histopathological examination showed aphthoid ulcerations and focal crypt abscesses. Which of the following genes is associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Crohn's disease. It is strongly associated with mutations in the nucleotide oligomerization binding domain 2 (NOD2) gene.

Crohn's disease occurs due to the host response against microbes. NOD2 encodes an intracellular protein that binds to bacterial peptidoglycans and activates the NF-κB pathway. Antibodies against the bacterial protein flagellin may be seen in NOD2-associated disease. 

Other Crohn's disease-related genes are autophagy-related 16-like (ATG16L1), and immunity-related GTPase M (IRGM), which are critical for cellular responses to intracellular bacteria.

Crohn's disease most commonly involves the terminal ileum but can affect all parts of the GIT. The following microscopic changes may be seen: 

  • Aphthoid ulcerations 
  • Focal crypt abscesses 
  • Non-caseating granulomas can be found in all layers of the bowel, lymph nodes, mesentery, peritoneum, liver, and pancreas

Note: Ulcerative colitis-associated genes are ECM1 and HNFA.

questions.text: An endoscopy was performed on a patient who presented with lower abdominal pain and severe diarrhea. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario along with cobblestone appearance on endoscopy is suggestive of Crohn's disease. This condition is associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis, not primary biliary cirrhosis.

Extraintestinal manifestations of Crohn's disease include the following:

  • Uveitis
  • Migratory polyarthritis
  • Sacroiliitis
  • Ankylosing spondylitis
  • Erythema nodosum
  • Clubbing of the fingertips
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis (less frequently than ulcerative colitis)
  • Cutaneous granulomas form nodules referred to as metastatic Crohn's disease (a misnomer since there is no cancer)

questions.text: Which of the following gross findings would you see in the resected bowel segment of a patient with ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
In ulcerative colitis, regenerating mucosa often bulges into the lumen to create pseudopolyps and the tips of these polyps may fuse to create mucosal bridges.

Features characteristic of ulcerative colitis are:

  • Proctocolitis/ backwash ileitis
  • Mucosa and superficial submucosal involvement
  • Broad-based ulcers
  • Pseudopolyps and mucosal bridges
  • Toxic megacolon

Note: Granulomas, strictures, and mural thickening are features of Crohn's disease.

questions.text:
p-ANCA is positive in which of the following conditions?
  1. Ulcerative colitis
  2. Crohn's disease
  3. Henoch-Schönlein purpura
  4. Churg–Strauss syndrome
  5. Microscopic polyangiitis
questions.solution:
Henoch-Schönlein purpura is associated with IgA immune complex deposition in the small vessels, not p-ANCA.

The following conditions are positive for perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (p-ANCA):

  • Ulcerative colitis
  • Crohn's disease
  • Churg–Strauss syndrome
  • Microscopic polyangiitis
Antibodies Ulcerative colitis Crohn's disease
p-ANCA Present in majority (75%) Present in minority (11%)
Antibodies to Saccharomyces cerevisiae Absent  Present

Related Pearl: ANCA Antibodies

The antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are the antibodies that are targeted against the specific proteins present in neutrophils and monocytes. They can be further classified as:

 

Cytoplasmic ANCA (cANCA)

 Perinuclear ANCA (pANCA)

Directed against

Proteinase 3 (PR3)

 Myeloperoxidase (MPO)

Predominantly positive in

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener granulomatosis)

Microscopic polyangiitis

Churg–Strauss syndrome 

Crescentic glomerulonephritis

Inflammatory Bowel Disease

Staining pattern

Granular cytoplasmic staining

Perinuclear or nuclear staining

questions.text: A pathology resident notes flask-shaped ulcers in an intestinal biopsy sample. This is characteristic of infections caused by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Flask-shaped ulcers are characteristic of amoebiasis, which is caused by Entamoeba histolytica. 

It most often affects the cecum and ascending colon. Parasites may also penetrate splanchnic vessels and embolize to the liver to produce amoebic liver abscesses. 

Image showing flask-shaped ulcers of amoebiasis:

Option A: In TB, ulcers are perpendicular to the axis of the intestine (transverse ulcers).

Option B: In typhoid, ulcers are oriented along the axis of the intestine (longitudinal ulcers).

Option C: Ulceration is not a feature of giardiasis.

questions.text:
Microscopic colitis encompasses which of the following?
  1. Collagenous colitis
  2. Ulcerative colitis
  3. Ischemic colitis
  4. Lymphocytic colitis
  5. Hemorrhagic colitis
questions.solution:
Microscopic colitis encompasses two types of disorders - collagenous colitis and lymphocytic colitis.

Collagenous colitis Lymphocytic colitis
Dense subepithelial collagen layer Subepithelial collagen layer is of normal thickness
Increased numbers of intraepithelial lymphocytes Higher ratio of intraepithelial lymphocytes

Lymphocytic colitis shows a strong association between celiac disease and autoimmune diseases, including Graves disease and rheumatoid arthritis.

These idiopathic diseases both present with chronic, non-bloody, watery diarrhea without weight loss.

questions.text: A 19-year-old boy with suspected acute appendicitis underwent laparoscopic appendectomy and the resected specimen was sent for histopathological examination. Presence of which of the following is considered confirmatory of this condition?

choices.text: Neutrophilic infiltration of the muscularis propria
Eosinophilic infiltration of the muscularis propria

questions.solution:
The diagnosis of acute appendicitis is confirmed by the presence of neutrophilic infiltration of the muscularis propria.

Surgical exploration is done when clinical suspicion for appendicitis is high but imaging studies are negative, nondiagnostic, or unavailable. In such situations, appendicitis can only be diagnosed intraoperatively or pathologically.
